A synthetic scheme for particle engineering of magnesium ethoxide (Mg(OEt)2) as a solid precursor for olefin polymerization catalysts was presented based on the exploitation of various organic compounds as a modulator in a post-addition step. It was found that the introduction of a modulator after the particle formation helped to modulate the macroscopic features and the crystalline structure of Mg(OEt)2 to the great extent without destructing the macroparticle morphology. Different types of organic compounds were exploited and their influences on the Mg(OEt)2 structural features were investigated. It was found that organic compounds with higher polarity caused strong modulation of Mg(OEt)2, which allowed particle and pore engineering of the final catalyst, and in turn its performance in propylene polymerization. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Magnesium ethoxide Post-addition Modulator Ziegler-Natta catalyst Polymerization 1 Introduction Heterogeneous catalysis is a complex phenomenon that couples the transport phenomena with the chemical reaction [1]. As the chemical reaction undergoes on the solid interfaces, macroscopic features and porous structures of catalyst particles explicitly play a decisive role on the transport properties which consequently affect the apparent activity and the selectivity of the products [2]. Hence, the catalyst particle is regarded as a part of the integral reactor system in which the specified properties need to be fulfilled to maximize the total performance of the catalytic process. Macroscopic features and porous structures of catalyst particles play an even more important role in olefin polymerization. Heterogeneous-catalyzed olefin polymerization is different from a typical solid-catalyzed reaction in the sense that polymer as a reaction product does not leave the solid surface. Instead, formed polymer fills up pores and generates the hydraulic force that causes the breakup of the catalyst macroparticle into small sub-units. Depending on the type of the solid support and the forming process, the particle breakup can happen in a layer-by-layer manner or in a sectioning manner [2–6], both of which induce the accessibility of monomer and the exposure of hidden active sites. Polymer continues to grow on the catalyst fragments that remain intact by surrounded polymer. The repetition of the polymerization-fragmentation process not only helps to extend the catalyst mileages, but also allows the polymer particle to replicate the morphology of the catalyst particle. Likewise, good polymer morphology with a narrow particle size distribution and a high bulk density for good operability and stable transfer operation can be achieved through the macroparticle design of catalysts. To induce particle breakup, monomer must diffuse through pores between sub-particles. At an early stage of polymerization, high volumetric rate of polymerization at the surface of macroparticles can cause diffusion-limited polymerization within the catalyst particles [7]. In the SiO2-supported catalyst system, mesopores of larger than 20 nm were reported to be necessary for rapid access of monomer required for the catalyst breakup [8]. It was further showed that for such a rigid support, filled polymer in small pores does not create sufficient hydraulic force necessary for the particle breakup, leading to a low activity. Contrary, a MgCl2-supported catalyst can fragment in the presence of pores with a smaller size [9–11] or even without a measurable pore [12,13], while the recent statistical structure-performance correlation indicated the significant performance deterioration when the catalysts contained mesopores with the size below 10 nm [14]. Hence, the judicious design and control of macroscopic characteristics and pore structures of the catalyst are of primary importance for the plant operation and the production output. A magnesium ethoxide (Mg(OEt)2)-based Ziegler-Natta catalyst represents one of the most industrial important catalysts for propylene polymerization that exhibit good morphological control, high activity and high stereospecificity. The catalyst is generally synthesized from solid-state conversion of Mg(OEt)2 into MgCl2/TiCl4/(donor) using TiCl4 as a chlorinating agent. It is well-documented that the macroscopic features of the catalyst duplicate that of exploited Mg(OEt)2, allowing the catalyst macroscopic design to be executed in the step of the Mg(OEt)2 synthesis [14–18]. It is commonly accepted that Mg(OEt)2 precipitates from its soluble complex as a reaction product between Mg metal and ethanol in the presence of a halogen-containing compound as an initiator [19–23]. The precipitates grow on the Mg substrate before detaching into the solution, subsequently grow, and develop a round shape by shear force in the system. The final particles are made up by the stacking of hexagon-platelet building units that microscopically consist of aggregated nanocrystals of different sizes [18,19]. Many studies have revealed that the synthetic conditions exert strong influence on the particle size, the particle size distribution and the shape of Mg(OEt)2 particles [15,20–29]. On the other hand, the shape of the platelet building units and the crystalline structure can be remarkably atered only by the addition of a third component as a modulator [16–18,29], leading to the change in the pore structure of the final catalyst. While a modulator approach provides a way to engineer the catalyst pore structure, the addition of a third component during the Mg(OEt)2 synthesis often accompanies the destruction of macroparticles due to the disruption of the nucleation and the particle growth process [16,17]. Thus, the limited addition amount was applied to compromise the properties [18]. In this work, a synthetic scheme for macroparticle and structural designs of Mg(OEt)2 was proposed based on the exploitation of an organic compound as a modulator in the post-addition step. We found that the introduction of a modulator after the particle formation not only helped to tune morphological features, but also affected the crystalline structure to the great extent without destructing macroparticles. The change in these properties allowed particle and pore designs of the final catalyst, which consequently affected the propylene polymerization performance. 2 Experiments 2.1 Materials Mg powder (mean particle size = 234 µm) was provided by SCG Chemicals Co., Ltd. Ethanol (purity > 99.5%, Wako Pure Chemical Industries Ltd.) was used after purification with molecular sieve 3A. Iodine (I2, purity > 99%) was purchased from Merck KGaA. n-Heptane (purity > 99.5%) and toluene (purity > 99.5%) were dried over molecular sieve 3A, followed by N2 bubbling prior to use. All chemicals that were used as an organic modulator, titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4), and di-n-butylphthalate (DBP, purity > 98%) were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industry Ltd. Cyclohexylmethyldimethoxysilane (CMDMS) was purified by distillation under reduced pressure prior to use. Triethylaluminum (TEA, donated by Tosoh Finechem Co.) was used after diluting in heptane. Propylene of polymerization grade (donated by Japan Polypropylene Co., Ltd.) was used as delivered. 2.2 Magnesium ethoxide synthesis Magnesium ethoxide (Mg(OEt)2) was synthesized from the reaction between Mg and ethanol in the presence of I2 as an initiator. The reaction was performed in a 500 mL glass reactor equipped with a mechanical stirrer according to the previously reported procedure with some modifications [15]. Briefly, 0.68 g of I2 and 31.7 mL of ethanol were charged into the reactor under N2. The temperature was raised to 75 °C under stirring at 180 rpm. After the dissolution of I2, 3.0 g of Mg powder and 31.7 mL of ethanol were charged to the reactor. The same amount of Mg and ethanol was repeatedly added for another 8 times with the interval time of 10 min. After the last addition, a specified amount of an organic compound as a modulator was added to the mixture. The reaction was kept for 2 h under stirring at the refluxing temperature. The resultant product was washed with ethanol and heptane before drying under vacuum at room temperature. 2.3 Catalyst synthesis The reaction was carried out in a 500 mL 3-neck round bottom flask equipped with a mechanical stirrer under N2 atmosphere. 15.0 g of Mg(OEt)2 and 150 mL of toluene were charged into the flask. After cooling down to 5 °C using an ice bath, 30 mL of TiCl4 was dropwise added. The mixture was slowly heated to 90 °C. After the addition of 4.5 mL of DBP at 90 °C, the temperature was raised to 110 °C and kept for 2 h. The solid was washed twice with toluene and further treated with 30 mL of TiCl4 in 150 mL of toluene for 2 h at 110 °C. The resultant product was repetitively washed with heptane and dried under vacuum. 2.4 Characterization The morphology of Mg(OEt)2 was observed by a scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4100) operated at an accelerate voltage of 20 kV. Mg(OEt)2 powder was dispersed on a carbon tape under N2 atmosphere. The particle characteristics were acquired from the SEM images using ImageJ software. The relative span factor (RSF) and the circularity degree were determined according to Eqs. (1) and (2); (1) RSF = D 90 − D 10 D 50 (2) Circularity degree = 4 × π × area boundary length 2 where D 10, D 50, and D 90 are the cumulative number-based particle size at 10%, 50%, and 90%, respectively. The bulk density of Mg(OEt)2 powder was measured according to JIS K 6721 with the reduction of the measuring scale. The sample was poured into a vessel with known volume under N2 atmosphere, and the mass of the sample was measured. The crystalline structure of Mg(OEt)2 was analyzed by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, SmartLab., RIGAKU) using CuKα radiation at 40 kV and 30 mA. The measurement was performed based on a stepwise scanning in the range of 5–35° with the step of 0.1° per 30 s. The sample was loaded onto a glass holder under N2 atmosphere, and covered by a Mylar film to prevent the contact with moisture. The morphology of a catalyst sample was observed by SEM. The Ti content and the donor content of a catalyst were respectively analyzed by ultraviolet-visible spectrometry (UV−vis, Jasco V-670) and Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT/IR-4100, JASCO) according to the previously reported procedure [15]. N2 adsorption and desorption experiments were performed at 77 K using a BELSORP-max instrument (BEL JAPAN, Inc.). The sample was outgassed at 80 °C for 2 h in vacuo prior to the measurement. The pore volume (V micro-meso) was determined for the pore size of less than 50 nm based on the NLDFT method. 2.5 Polymerization procedure Propylene polymerization was conducted in a 1 L stainless steel reactor equipped with a mechanical stirrer rotating at 350 rpm. After atmospheric replacement by N2, 300 mL of heptane was charged into the reactor, followed by the addition of 3.0 mmol of TEA and 0.2 mmol of CMDMS as an activator and an external donor, respectively. The solvent was saturated with propylene at 50 °C and 5 atm for 30 min. Thereafter, a measured amount of a catalyst was charged for polymerization initiation. After 1 h of polymerization at 50 °C and 5 atm, the resultant polymer was collected by filtration and dried at 60 °C under vacuum for 6 h. 2.6 Polymer analysis All analyses of polymer samples were provided by SCG Chemicals Co., Ltd. The weight average molecular weight (M w) was analyzed by gel permeable chromatography (GPC-IR5, Polymer Char) using 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene as a solvent. The mesopentad sequence (mmmm) was analyzed by 13C NMR (500 MHz ASCEND™, Bruker) at 120 °C using 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene and 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d 2 as a solvent and an internal lock, respectively. The bulk density of polymer powder was measured according to JIS K 6721. 3 Results and discussions In our previous works, the addition of an organic compound as a modulator strongly affected the Mg(OEt)2 particle morphology, in which an excessive addition resulted in the destruction of the morphology [16,17]. At the same time, the modulator modulated the Mg(OEt)2 crystalline structure as a result of nucleation and growth disruption. This in turn led to the alternation of macroscopic features as well as the pore structure of the final catalyst. In order to exploit the advantages of a modulator strategy for Mg(OEt)2 particle tuning without sacrificing morphological features, the post-addition of the modulator was investigated in this work. Fig. 1 shows the morphology of Mg(OEt)2 synthesized in the presence of ethylene glycol at 5 mol%, in which its addition was done either at the beginning of the reaction (referred as pre-addition) or after the last sequential addition of the precursors (referred as post-addition). As compared to Mg(OEt)2 synthesized in the absence of ethylene glycol (Fig. 1a), the pre-addition of ethylene glycol obviously caused the distortion of the particle morphology with significant fine particle generation (Fig. 1b). Contrary, the spheroidal morphology was kept in the case of the post-addition (Fig. 1c). A significant difference in the particle characteristic between Mg(OEt)2 synthesized with the post-addition of ethylene glycol and without ethylene glycol was found at a considerably smaller particle size for the former. To understand the role of the modulator, a small portion of the reaction intermediate after the last sequential addition of the precursors was collected. Fig. 2a shows that the spheroidal morphology was already developed for this intermediate sample with D 50 and RSF values of 26.8 µm and 0.36 as compared to 37.5 µm and 0.27 for the fully grown particles (Fig. 2b). The platelet building units (Fig. 2c) were also much smaller than that of the fully grown one (Fig. 2d). As the Mg(OEt)2 particle development proceeds through seed/cluster generation, detachment from Mg surfaces and subsequent growth [19–23], the similar spheroidal morphology and particle size distribution between the reaction intermediate and the final product suggested that no new cluster was formed during aging. Note that D 50 of Mg(OEt)2 synthesized with the post-addition of ethylene glycol was 28.3 µm, lied in between the reaction intermediate and the fully grown particles. This indicated that the introduction of the modulator in the post-addition step helped to modulate Mg(OEt)2 particles in the particle growth stage. This brought several advantages, such as preservation of the morphology and particle size distribution, as well as the possibility to tune pore characteristics during the ripening process. In another point of view, fine-tuning of the particle size was limited within the growth range, i.e. between 26.8 and 37.5 µm. In Table 1, various types of organic compounds were employed in the post-addition step and their influences on the Mg(OEt)2 particle characteristics were investigated. In all cases, the spheroidal morphology was observed ( Fig. 3). From magnified SEM images ( Fig. 4), most of the samples exhibited typical platelet building units, except for ethylene glycol that showed an irregular shape. With the addition of methanol and 2-methoxy ethanol, the shape of the platelets changed from hexagon-like to round-like ones. It is notable that most of the obtained Mg(OEt)2 samples exhibited the particle size in a similar range to Mg(OEt)2 synthesized in the absence of the modulator. Only the addition of 2-methoxy ethanol and ethylene glycol gave Mg(OEt)2 with a significantly smaller particle size. On the other hand, the bulk density for all of the samples increased with the addition of the modulator in which the largest increment was found for 2-methoxy ethanol and ethylene glycol. From these results, it is apparent that the extent of the particle modulation is largely correlated with polarity of the exploited modulators. For instance, organic compounds having higher polarity than ethanol tended to give the reaction product with drastic changes in the particle characteristics, especially for the particle size and the bulk density. The influence of the modulator amount added in the post-addition step was further investigated for methanol, 1-butanol, and 2-methoxy ethanol. SEM images in Fig. 5 show that all of the samples possessed the spheroidal morphology with the uniform particle size distribution. In the case of methanol and 2-methoxy ethanol, the shape of the building units gradually changed with increasing the addition amount from platelets to a round-like shape for methanol, and to tiny aggregated building units having an irregular shape for 2-methoxy ethanol. On the other hand, no significant change in the platelet morphology was observed for 1-butanol. As shown in Table 2, the increase in the addition amount for methanol and 2-methoxy ethanol also caused the decrease in the particle size. The extent of the particle size reduction was greater for the latter, which also accompanied a greater increment in the bulk density. At 15 mol% of the 2-methoxy ethanol addition, the bulk density reached 0.43 g cm−1. Such the high bulk density with the spheroidal morphology and narrow particle size distribution is hardly achieved by varying the condition in the Mg(OEt)2 synthesis. Contrary, no significant change in the particle size was observed for 1-butanol, similar to the result for its platelet morphology. To understand the origin of modulation efficiency difference between 2-methoxy ethanol and methanol, the solubility of Mg(OEt)2 was investigated by 1H NMR (Fig. S1, Supplementary Information). It was found that the solubility of Mg(OEt)2 in 2-methoxy ethanol was much larger than in methanol (0.48 mol mol−1 for 2-methoxy ethanol and 0.06 mol mol−1 for methanol). This might explain the greater impact of 2-methoxy ethanol as compared to methanol on the properties of Mg(OEt)2 at the same addition amount. The XRD patterns of Mg(OEt)2 prepared in the absence and presence of ethylene glycol, methanol, 2-methoxy ethanol, and 1-butanol are shown in Fig. 6. The XRD pattern of Mg(OEt)2 exhibited several overlapping peaks in the range of 7–13°. Four intense peaks at 9.1, 9.9, 10.8, and 11.1° and a shoulder at 9.5° are typically observed for fully grown Mg(OEt)2 particles [17–19,22]. In the presence of the modulators, additional four peaks (or shoulders) at 8.9, 10.1, 10.6, and 11.6° were evolved. They were similarly observed during the growth of Mg(OEt)2, and were ascribed as metastable phases [22]. These metastable phases transformed into the final phase during the aging step (i.e., at 140 min of the reaction in ref. [22]). In the “Oswald’s Rule of Stages”, the crystallization from a supersaturated solution involves a series of transient metastable phases with a low nucleation barrier [30]. Once the formation of nuclei of a more stable phase is triggered, metastable crystals will ripen on nanoscale nuclei of a more stable phase, and will be spontaneously consumed. Here, we demonstrated the persistence of these metastable phases in the presence of the modulators. Their fractions also increased with the increase in the addition amount and polarity of the modulators. The persistence of the metastable phases might be explained by the size-dependent solubility of the stable phase. In a multiple phase system, a nucleus of a stable phase will grow under the condition that its size-dependent solubility is lower than the bulk solubility of the metastable phase [31]. It is plausible that the addition of high polarity compounds increases the solubility of the system, thus inhibiting the formation of stable phase nuclei. Fig. 7 illustrates the proposed schematic diagram for the Mg(OEt)2 particle development and the phase transformation when a high polarity organic compound is introduced in the post-addition step. Although the development of Mg(OEt)2 particles and the phase transformation are different events, they cooperatively contribute to the final macroparticle properties. At first, nuclei of a lowest-nucleation barrier metastable phase nucleate and aggregate on Mg particles. The presence of shear force causes the detachment of the growing clusters from Mg surfaces to the solution. The clusters of metastable crystals grow, shape into spheroidal macroparticles, and consume the solute until they become equilibrate with the solution. At this point, no new clusters of the metastable phase are generated as they possess too high chemical potential. This explains a similar particle size distribution between the intermediate and the final product. To progress the crystallization into the next stage, nuclei of a more stable phase are formed within the developed particles. The solution becomes undersaturation with respect to the metastable phase. This causes the dissolution and reprecipitation of the metastable crystals on more stable phase nuclei. Finally, the crystals of the stable phase continue to grow and self-assemble into platelets as building units of macroparticles. By the addition of high polarity compounds in the post-addition step, the solubility of Mg(OEt)2 increases, thus inhibiting the formation of stable phase nuclei. Due to densely packed features of the metastable phase building units, the apparent size of macroparticles becomes smaller with a higher bulk density. Industrial usefulness of Mg(OEt)2 as a solid precursor for olefin polymerization catalysts is essentially determined by the preservation of the macroparticle morphology during the solid-state conversion into a MgCl2/TiCl4/(donor) catalyst. We previously reported that Mg(OEt)2 particles that consist of too loosely, unevenly or even too tightly packed platelet building units can undergo particle disintegration due to the collision and high exothermicity of the reaction with TiCl4 [14]. Among the Mg(OEt)2 samples, Mg(OEt)2 synthesized in the presence of 2-methoxy ethanol exhibited the greatest change in the building unit morphology and the bulk density. Therefore, they were selected for the catalyst preparation. From Fig. 8(a), in the absence of the modulator, the morphology of the catalyst well resembled that of exploited Mg(OEt)2. The modification of Mg(OEt)2 with 2-methoxy ethanol did not cause the destruction of the particle integrity during catalyzation up to the addition amount of 10 mol% (Fig. 8b,c), while fragments and fine particles were observed at 15 mol% (Fig. 8d). Such the morphological failure was believed to associate with too tightly packed small aggregated building units of Mg(OEt)2 particles. The chemical compositions for all catalyst samples exhibited a typical composition range for Mg(OEt)2-based Ziegler-Natta catalysts ( Table 3) [14,15]. The Ti and donor contents decreased with the increase in the 2-methoxy ethanol addition amount, while the molar ratio between Ti and donor was kept almost unchanged. XRD analysis was performed on CAT-None, CAT-5 mol% and CAT-10 mol% in order to identify the difference in the crystalline structure of the formed MgCl2 crystals (Fig. S1, Supplementary Information). Typically, crystalline MgCl2 (α-MgCl2) exhibits the diffraction peaks at 15.1°, 29°, 30.4°, 35.0°, 50.2° and 52.8°, corresponding to (003), (101), (012) and (006), (104), (110) and (018), and (113) facets of MgCl2 crystals [32]. On the other hand, the catalyst samples exhibited the broad peaks at 2θ = 14.4°, 28–35°, and 50–53°, which are the feature of disordered MgCl2 [32]. The shift of the (003) peak to a smaller angle with significant broadening for the catalyst samples indicated the thinning of the crystal along the c-axis. Broadening/merging of the peak at around 2θ = 28–35° arose from the stacking disorder of the MgCl2 layer, while broadening/merging of the peaks at around 2θ = 50–53° indicated the size reduction along the a,b-axes. From the XRD profiles, the dimensions of MgCl2 crystallites were estimated from the (003) and (110) diffractions based on the Scherrer equation. It was found that the thickness of MgCl2 along the c-axis (~20 Å) corresponds to 3–4 layers of Mg-Cl-Mg, similar for all of the catalyst samples (Table S1). The lateral dimension was in the range of 48–64 Å, smallest for CAT-None and largest for CAT-10 mol%. In addition to the crystallite dimension, the detail of stacking disorder was also found to be slightly different. Namely, the peaks at 2θ = 28–35°, were completely merged into a single broad peak for CAT-None whereas some level of splitting was still evidenced for CAT-5 mol% and CAT-10 mol%. This indicated the greater extent of stacking disorder for the former. From these results, it was plausible that the change in the Mg(OEt)2 crystalline structure by the post-addition of 2-methoxy ethanol affected the formed MgCl2 crystals, resulting in alternation of the lateral surfaces available for TiCl4 and donor adsorption. In Table 3, the resultant catalysts possessed a slightly larger particle size than their relevant Mg(OEt)2. This is typically observed in a Mg(OEt)2-based catalyst system due to the removal of small particles by decantation during the repetitive washing. The pore volume in the micro- and mesopore regions was found to increase with increasing the amount of 2-methoxy ethanol. It must be noted that interparticle voids between platelet building units of typical Mg(OEt)2 are larger than mesopores, and are not included in the pore volume derived from the N2 adsorption branch (see a typical mercury intrusion profile of Mg(OEt)2 in Fig. S3, Supplementary Information. This might explain a small difference in the pore volume between CAT-None and CAT-5 mol%, which prepared from Mg(OEt)2 that exhibited the characteristic of platelet building units. On the other hand, CAT-10 mol% showed a significant increment in the pore volume. Considering the substantial change in the building unit morphology between 5 mol% and 10 mol% of the 2-methoxy ethanol addition, it was anticipated that interparticle voids created by the compaction of small aggregated building units contributed to the pore volume increment. Propylene polymerization performances in Table 4 revealed that the catalysts prepared from the modified Mg(OEt)2 exhibited a higher catalytic activity as compared to the unmodified one regardless of a lower Ti content. Though the increase in the catalytic activity is hardly described based on a single parameter due to multiple interplays between structural and chemical factors, available literature showed that the activity in solid-catalyzed olefin polymerization tended to increase with the decrease in the catalyst particle size and the increase in the pore volume [7,14,18,33–35] due to the decrease in mass transfer resistances. These tendencies were in line with the observed results. The molecular weight and the stereoregularity of the resultant polymer were found to be similar, signifying a similar active site nature among catalysts. The polymer bulk density was slightly higher for the modified support. This might come from a higher bulk density of catalyst particles and/or a higher product yield in which the formed polymer filled up voids to create denser particles. From these results, the addition of the modulator in the post-addition step has advantages not only for the ease of the morphological control, but also for tuning the catalyst properties to significantly improve the polymerization performance. 4 Conclusions The synthetic scheme for macroparticle and structural design of Mg(OEt)2 as a solid precursor for olefin polymerization catalysts was demonstrated based on the exploitation of an organic compound as a modulator in the post-addition step. We found that the introduction of the modulator after the last sequential addition of the precursors helped to modulate Mg(OEt)2 particles, especially for the particle size, the bulk density and the morphology of Mg(OEt)2 building units, without destructing the macroparticle morphology. The extent of the particle modulation was found to be correlated with polarity of the exploited modulator. For instance, organic compounds having higher polarity than ethanol tended to give the reaction product with drastic changes in macroparticle and structural features. It is believed that a high polarity compound increased the solubility of Mg(OEt)2 to affect the dissolution/precipitation of the crystals during the particle growth process. This perturbed the particle growth and phase transformation, which consequently altered the final properties of Mg(OEt)2 especially for the particle size and the bulk density. Usefulness of Mg(OEt)2 prepared through the new synthetic scheme was demonstrated by the conversion into the catalyst. It was found that the morphology of the catalyst well-resembled that of exploited Mg(OEt)2, while the pore volume of the catalyst increased with the increased amount of a high polarity modulator. This was believed to arise from interparticle voids created by the compaction of small aggregated building units. With the decrease in the particle size and the increase in the pore volume, the performance in propylene polymerization significantly increased. Till the end, we successfully proved that macroparticle and structural modulation of Mg(OEt)2 through the post-addition of a modulator allowed particle engineering of the final catalyst to consequently affect the propylene polymerization performance. coredata.dc:description: A synthetic scheme for particle engineering of magnesium ethoxide (Mg(OEt)2) as a solid precursor for olefin polymerization catalysts was presented based on the exploitation of various organic compounds as a modulator in a post-addition step. It was found that the introduction of a modulator after the particle formation helped to modulate the macroscopic features and the crystalline structure of Mg(OEt)2 to the great extent without destructing the macroparticle morphology. Different types of organic compounds were exploited and their influences on the Mg(OEt)2 structural features were investigated. It was found that organic compounds with higher polarity caused strong modulation of Mg(OEt)2, which allowed particle and pore engineering of the final catalyst, and in turn its performance in propylene polymerization.
coredata.dc:title: Particle engineering of magnesium ethoxide-based Ziegler-Natta catalyst through post-modification of magnesium ethoxide
